items.title: Domain Socket connection config is broken.
items.body:
It defaults to a tcp connection even when the unix_domain_socket_path  is specified as the redis_host parameter is not None since it sets itself to localhost due to the line.
 
`SESSION_REDIS_HOST = SESSION_REDIS.get('host', 'localhost')`

For domain socket connection to work, either the host parameter should be explicitly set to None or the following lines in _sessions.py_ could be changed,

```
if settings.SESSION_REDIS_URL is not None:
         self.connection_type = 'redis_url'
elif settings.SESSION_REDIS_HOST is not None:
          self.connection_type = 'redis_host'
elif settings.SESSION_REDIS_UNIX_DOMAIN_SOCKET_PATH is not None:
          self.connection_type = 'redis_unix_url'
```
to,

```
if settings.SESSION_REDIS_URL is not None:
         self.connection_type = 'redis_url'
elif settings.SESSION_REDIS_UNIX_DOMAIN_SOCKET_PATH is not None:
          self.connection_type = 'redis_unix_url'
elif settings.SESSION_REDIS_HOST is not None:
          self.connection_type = 'redis_host'

```

This way, we check for the unix_domain_socket_path before the redis_host.

items.title: when will release the new tag
items.body: can tell when will you release the new release to fix the bug in get SESSION_REDIS_HOST,I see the master is fix but pip is the old code..

items.title: Settings file broken
items.body:
The settings.py file is trying to pull each setting from a dict, but it's calling `getattr` which will not work, so it always uses the defaults.

E.g.,

`SESSION_REDIS_HOST = getattr(SESSION_REDIS, 'host', 'localhost')`

Should be:

`SESSION_REDIS_HOST = SESSION_REDIS.get('host', 'localhost')`

items.title: session.py problem
items.body:
in session.py line 79 
"elif self.connection_type == 'unix_url':"
Should't be
"elif self.connection_type == 'redis_host':" ?

items.title: setting.py，Could not get properties for  SESSION_REDIS

items.title: Release tags in github?
items.body:
Hi there!

We use the library and since the changelog only contains the most recent release 0.5.6, I was wondering if you'd possibly add tags to when each release was cut so as to allow for better inspection of a given version.

I recognize this might be harder to go back, but starting with the current release would be enough to get started.

Thanks!

items.title: Update sessionid expires value
items.body:
Hey!

I use django-redis-sessions for session backend, here is my configuration:

```
SESSION_CACHE_ALIAS = 'redis'
SESSION_COOKIE_AGE = 3600 * 24 * 7
SESSION_ENGINE = 'django.contrib.sessions.backends.cache'

CACHES = {
    'redis': {
        'BACKEND': 'redis_cache.RedisCache',
        'LOCATION': '{0}:{1}'.format(REDIS_HOST, REDIS_PORT),
    }
}
```

The problem here is that sessionid key in cookies does not update and lives precisely for 1 week and users have to relogin every week.

Is there a way for sessionid to autoupdate on every request from user?

items.title: build failing with IOError (cannot find README)
items.body:
When trying to install the current build for version 0.5.5 with `pip install django-redis-sessions` it fails with:

```
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-build-Y06Tjv/django-redis-sessions/README.md'
```

It also shows up in Travis: https://travis-ci.org/martinrusev/django-redis-sessions/jobs/136061874

Hi Martin,

would it be possible to make a new release? The sentinel features are very interesting

Thanks!

items.title: Security release
items.body: Hello, was wondering if you're planning to release new version with the security patch today?

items.title: Allow configuration of connection pool to use
items.body:
Every Redis instance, by default, creates and manages its own connection pool (https://github.com/andymccurdy/redis-py#connection-pools). In certain situations, it's useful to be able to manage connection pooling yourself. (In my case, I have a limited number of total connections available through a third-party hosted Redis service.) 

I would be happy to take a stab at coding this up and sending a pull request, if you'd be open to it. I imagine it would be an optional setting such as:

`SESSION_REDIS_CONNECTION_POOL = 'myproj.utils.RedisConnectionPool'`

Do you have any initial guidance on how you'd want such a feature implemented? Would you be open to this?

items.title: Add script to copy over the current session tables in the database to redis
items.body:
Hi,

Do you happen to have such a script? It might make things easier for people to switch to this app.

Best,

Ustun

http://pypi.python.org/pypi/django-redis-sessions

items.title: Redis config from url
items.body: It would be useful to parse Redis settings from an url (i.e. redis.from_url()). This would help with Heroku.

items.title: Proposal: dict config
items.body:
Since dictionary configs become very popular (like `django.conf.settings.DATABASES`) or `logging` [configuration style](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0391/), shouldn't it be better to make one setting like a `SESSION_REDIS` which will looks like this?

```
SESSION_REDIS = {
    'HOST': 'localhost',
    'PORT': 6379,
    'DB': 0,
    'PREFIX': 'session',
}
```

Also, like in a Django, if `HOST` starts with a '/', it would assumes, that it is an Unix socket, and empty string should assumes an `localhost` address.

items.title: Session store should not directly set session_key
items.body:
In session.py:

```
def create(self):
    while True:
        self.session_key = self._get_new_session_key()
```

should be:

```
        self._session_key = self._get_new_session_key()
```

items.title: Raises and AttributeError on django 1.4c2
items.body:
session_key is readonly since https://code.djangoproject.com/changeset/17155 changeset. 
Changing 
  self.session_key = self._get_new_session_key()

To
  self._session_key = self._get_new_session_key()
in create() method fixed error for me.

items.title: PyPi version not in sync with repo
items.body:
There have been a few major changes (e.g. tabs to spaces, inclusion of redis session setting, etc)--would love to see these on PyPi.

Thanks!

items.title: Post to PyPI
items.body:
For development and deployment it's very helpful to be able to say `pip install -U django-redis-sessions==0.2` (or whatever).

As far as I can tell (from watchers & forks), this is the most popular redis session backend for Django, but it's not up on PyPI yet (and the name is still free, despite the other project with the same name on BitBucket).  Post to PyPI while you still can. :-)

items.title: Automatic Redis Session expiry?
items.body:
Hi Martin, it would be great if you could add automatic Redis key expiry. Currently you do encode the session expiry in the key but the key does not expire in Redis itself, so sessions clutter the database over time.
Note that the default "manage.py cleanup" doesn't touch the Redis sessions as it only works on the sessions database tables. (Django bug, IMHO!)
Should be a no-brainer... - Thanks, Felix
